profileAlternative.name: Monica Beckwith
profileAlternative.headline: Java Champion, First Lego League Coach, Passionate about JVM Performance at Microsoft
profileAlternative.summary:
Java Champion Monica Beckwith is considered a subject matter expert, has several published articles and gets regular invitations to give talks on JVM/JIT Compilation/Garbage Collection (GC). She is also a JavaOne Rock Star.
Monica has made various performance contributions to the Java HotSpot VM by identifying the need for a NUMA-aware allocator and allocation patterns, reduction of redundant instructions, reduction of the Java object header, prefetching patterns, redundant array checks in a loop and various other optimizations for the JIT compiler, the generated code, the JVM heuristics and garbage collection and collectors.
Prior to joining Microsoft, Monica was the JVM Performance Architect at Arm. Her past also includes leading Oracle’s Garbage First Garbage Collector performance team.

Monica has co-authored the 'Java Performance Companion' book and is currently working on a book that would cover Java 11 features.
Monica is considered one of the influential women in Java and Scala:
https://twitter.com/java/status/1122930296423440384?s=19
https://twitter.com/javinpaul/status/1134657350906683392?s=19
https://twitter.com/javinpaul/status/1133734555385360386?s=19
https://www.instana.com/blog/20-developer-experts-to-follow-on-twitter/ http://blog.takipi.com/10-influential-women-in-java-scala-and-everything-in-between/

Monica is on the program committee and co-chair for QCon San Francisco, JAX London, JFokus, HeapCon, etc. She is a champion of girls in STEAM and loves volunteering her time in coaching kids in the field of (Java) programming and more recently, Lego Robotics.

You can catch Monica online @mon_beck (Twitter) and also look up her presentations @SlideShare

given.text:
Monica worked for me as a co-op on two occasions, in the Fall of 2002 and again in the Summer of 2003. The first term, Monica supported my HyperTracer team, developing and debugging C++ programs and perl scripts. HyperTracer is a tool developed by the HyperTracer team to regenerate the exact instruction stream (typically 300 to 400 million instructions) that was executed by a target platform. The team had to hide memory from the operating system, stop the cpu at a user-specified time, dump the system state, set up a special tracking mode which would send tracking information to a memory buffer, then dump the buffer to file, and regenerate the instruction stream via a software model of the cpu. Monica wrote some of the scripts we used to transfer data between machines for a post-processing farm and some of the programs used to hide memory from the system. On her second term, Monica worked on evaluating the performance of SpecJBB. Her assignment was to evaluate SpecJBB’s performance to extrapolate the benefits of either doubling the L2 cache or adding a second cpu core. Monica completed the analysis and generated a report of her findings for AMD which was also used for her thesis. Monica successfully completed the tasks involved with both of her terms. It was good to have her back for a second term. She is self-driven, resourceful, personable, and accepts responsibility well. She was a valuable asset to the team.

I worked with Monica for over 4 years doing deep dive analysis of Java Performance on the latest SPARC processors. Monica is talented Engineer with an inquisitive mind and an extremely strong work ethic. She is always prepared to go the extra mile to get the root of performance issues. Her skills include a deep knowledge of Java internals, OS tuning, hardware counters and system architecture. I highly recommend Monica for any performance role.

In Monica's relatively brief tenure at Spansion, she made a lot of impact. Her aggressive and smart contributions to performance analysis and benchmarking for a new, flash-based DRAM replacement product for server applications helped increase my and our collective understanding of the system, which was largely developed by a third party. I recommend her skills and contributions in a team environment where insight and rapid results are valued...

I worked briefly under her guidance as an intern during my stint at L&T. Monica's strong fundamentals on embedded technologies and her willingness to teach starting from a grass-root level helped me immensely in my engineering days.

received.text: During my Masters, I worked as a co-op for AMD and Jody was my manager. Today anything that I know about Server Performance, benchmarking, Server tuning, NUMA architecture, Opteron Architecture is all thanks to Jody. He mentored me during all my co-ops at AMD and I think I am a fine Performance engineer, thanks to him and his team. I really appreciate the opportunity to be able to learn from the very best - Jody!

John's a practical manager with a great foresight. I enjoyed having a manager that was intellectually stimulating and would encourage the growth of ideas. John's a well-organized people's person and I find it amazing how he's a perfect blend of technical and managerial skills!

I highly recommend him to any company looking for experienced senior managers to manage any team, be it customer relations, engineering, technical marketing, etc.
